application.ref: A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

text.p: the authors claimed that every G-metric space is D * -metric. In this short paper we present examples to show that D * -metric need not be G-metric as well as the G-metric need not be D * -metric.the authors claimed that every G-metric space is D * -metric. In this short paper we present examples to show that D * -metric need not be G-metric as well as the G-metric need not be D * -metric.

In 2005, Zead and Sims [5] introduced the notion of G-metric spaces as a generalization of the concept of ordinary metric spaces as follows.In 2005, Zead and Sims [5] introduced the notion of G-metric spaces as a generalization of the concept of ordinary metric spaces as follows.

Definition 1.1 ([5]). A G-metric space is a pair (A, G), where A is a nonempty set, and G : A × A × A → [0, ∞) such that for all κ, λ, , ζ ∈ A we haveDefinition 1.1 ([5]). A G-metric space is a pair (A, G), where A is a nonempty set, and G : A × A × A → [0, ∞) such that for all κ, λ, , ζ ∈ A we have

Many authors obtained fixed point results for different contractive mappings in the frame work of G-metric space, for more details we refer the reader to [1][2][3][4][5].Many authors obtained fixed point results for different contractive mappings in the frame work of G-metric space, for more details we refer the reader to [1][2][3][4][5].
In 2007, Sedghi et al. introduced the concept of D * -metric space as follows.In 2007, Sedghi et al. introduced the concept of D * -metric space as follows.

The function D * is called a D * -metric on A.The function D * is called a D * -metric on A.

Many authors obtained fixed point results under some contractive conditions, see [6,8]. Note that every D * -metric on A defines a metric d D * on A byMany authors obtained fixed point results under some contractive conditions, see [6,8]. Note that every D * -metric on A defines a metric d D * on A by
). Let A be a D * -metric space, then the function D * (κ, λ, ) is jointly continuous on A × A × A.). Let A be a D * -metric space, then the function D * (κ, λ, ) is jointly continuous on A × A × A.

In [7, Remark 1.3], Sedghi et al. claimed that "every G-metric space is D * -metric". The following example shows that this claim need not be true in general.In [7, Remark 1.3], Sedghi et al. claimed that "every G-metric space is D * -metric". The following example shows that this claim need not be true in general.

In fact, every non-symmetric G-metric space is not D * -metric. Now we present an example shows that D * -metric need not to be G-metric. [8]. But D * is not G-metric since (G3) is not satisfied. In fact, D * (5, 5, 10) = 20 18 = D * (5, 10, 9). However, the following is an example of both G-metric and D * -metric.In fact, every non-symmetric G-metric space is not D * -metric. Now we present an example shows that D * -metric need not to be G-metric. [8]. But D * is not G-metric since (G3) is not satisfied. In fact, D * (5, 5, 10) = 20 18 = D * (5, 10, 9). However, the following is an example of both G-metric and D * -metric.
